description: Knez Mihailova Street is the main pedestrian and shopping zone in Belgrade, protected by law as one of the oldest and most valuable landmarks of the city. Named after Mihailo Obrenović, a Serbian Prince, it features numerous buildings built during the 1870s.

history.ancient_origins: The roots of Knez Mihailova trace back to the Roman city of Singidunum, where this vital passage carved its way as the main access route into the fortified heart of the settlement, aligning with the Roman via cardo.

protection.1964: Protected as the spatial cultural-historical unit, the first cultural monument of that type in Belgrade
protection.1979: Elevated to Spatial Cultural-Historical Units of Great Importance

history.pedestrianization: For much of the 20th century the street was open to traffic and parking. In 1987 the city decided to pedestrianize it, and since then it has become the central symbol of Belgrade.

characteristics.architecture: Buildings from the 1870s featuring Neo-Renaissance and Neo-Baroque styles
characteristics.recognition: Named one of the most beautiful pedestrian zones in South East Europe

shopping.amenities: Numerous cafes, restaurants, and entertainment venues

visitor_experience.atmosphere: Always busy with a lively atmosphere
visitor_experience.activities: Shopping, dining, people watching, street performances
visitor_experience.connection: Street extends to Republic Square and leads directly to Kalemegdan Fortress

cultural_significance: Central symbol of Belgrade since pedestrianization, serving as the main commercial and social hub of the city
interesting_facts: Follows the ancient Roman via cardo from Singidunum
First cultural monument of its type protected in Belgrade (1964)
One kilometer of uninterrupted pedestrian zone
Named after Prince Mihailo Obrenović, who liberated Belgrade from Ottoman rule
One of the most beautiful pedestrian zones in Southeast Europe
